patterns: what are the symptoms of covid
responses:
Most common symptoms:
fever
dry cough
tiredness
Less common symptoms:
aches and pains
sore throat
diarrhoea
conjunctivitis
headache
loss of taste or smell
a rash on skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes

To prevent the spread of COVID-19:
Clean your hands often. Use soap and water, or an alcohol-based hand rub.
Maintain a safe distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing.
Wear a mask when physical distancing is not possible.
Don’t touch your eyes, nose or mouth.
Cover your nose and mouth with your bent elbow or a tissue when you cough or sneeze.
Stay home if you feel unwell.
If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention.

When cooking and preparing food, limit the amount of salt and high-sodium condiments (e.g. soy sauce and fish sauce).
 Limit your daily salt intake to less than 5 g (approximately 1 teaspoon), and use iodized salt.
 Avoid foods (e.g. snacks) that are high in salt and sugar.
 Limit your intake of soft drinks or sodas and other drinks that are high in sugar (e.g. fruit juices, fruit juice concentrates and syrups, flavoured milks and yogurt drinks).
 Choose fresh fruits instead of sweet snacks such as cookies, cakes and chocolate.

Although for most people COVID-19 causes only mild illness, it can make some people very ill. More rarely, the disease can be fatal. Older people, and those with pre- existing medical conditions (such as high blood pressure, heart problems or diabetes) appear to be more vulnerable.

The best way to prevent the spread of infections and decrease the risk of getting sick is by washing your hands with plain soap and water, advises the CDC. Washing hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is essential, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after coughing, sneezing, or blowing one’s nose. If soap and water are not available, CDC recommends consumers use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.

The FDA has authorized the emergency use of face masks, including cloth face coverings, that meet certain criteria for use as source control by the general public and health care personnel in accordance with CDC recommendations during the COVID-19 public health emergency. The FDA also regulates other medical devices, including personal protective equipment (PPE) such as surgical masks and N95 respirators. The CDC recommends that PPE should be reserved for use by health care workers, first responders, and other frontline workers whose jobs put them at much greater risk of acquiring COVID-19.

patterns: I think I might have COVID
i think i might have covid
responses:
Hi! Don't worry and follow these steps: 
1. Do a survey here:https://covid19survey.ford.com/india  
2. Call on the helpline number +91-11-23978046
3. Visit the nearest COVID hospital

The COVID vaccine was launched on 16th January, 2021. The first group includes healthcare and frontline workers. The second group to receive COVID 19 vaccine will be persons over 50 years of age and persons under 50 years with comorbid conditions. You can check out more information here: https://www.mohfw.gov.in/covid_vaccination/vaccination/index.html#v-pills-prioritisation
All Statistics can be found here: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/india/

1. All passengers must submit a self-declaration form regarding their health, along with their Aarogya Setu app health data to certify themselves as being fit to fly
2. After security screening is complete, you can proceed to the holding area.
3. You must collect the face masks, face shield and sanitisers.
4. Ensure that you maintain social distancing norms and proper sanitation during this stage of the journey as well.
More information can be found here: https://www.yatra.com/online/government-guidelines
